title: EBay Founder Pierre Omidyar Steps Down From Board
summary: Elliott Management partner also leaves board of the online marketplace. EBay Inc. founder Pierre Omidyar stepped down from the company's board as part of a broader overhaul that also has Elliott Management Corp. partner Jesse Cohn leaving the board.

title: Stocks Close Lower After Early Gains
summary: Number of Americans filing for jobless benefits held steady from the prior week. Losses by big technology companies led U.S. stock declines on Thursday, pausing Wednesday's rebound after a recent technology-led selloff.

title: Second Top Female Executive at Bridgewater Says Firm Paid Her Less Than Men
summary: Complaint from Karen Karniol-Tambour, hedge fund's most senior female executive, follows gender-discrimination suit from former co-CEO. Karen Karniol-Tambour, the top-ranked woman at hedge fund Bridgewater Associates, is sparring with the firm over her pay after learning that she has earned less than some male counterparts, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Woodward's Non-Revelation
summary: There's no need for the tell-all books. Trump tells us every day.. The books professing dark revelations about President Trump appear to be lined up from here to Election Day, like aircraft heading into LaGuardia. This week it's Bob Woodward's turn, with the big news reportedly being that Mr. Trump told him in a taped conversation on Feb. 7 that he had played down the coronavirus despite knowing it was "deadly stuff."

title: Democrats Filibuster Covid Relief
summary: They block money for small business, schools and jobless benefits.. Congratulations to Mitch McConnell, who kept all but one of his GOP Senate majority together on Thursday to vote for a $500 billion virus relief bill. Senate Democrats filibustered the bill, though these are the same Democrats who say they'll kill the filibuster if they run the Senate next year. Thursday's filibuster exposes that Democratic spending demands are about exploiting Covid to bail out progressive states, not helping the public.

title: Black Cops Don't Matter
summary: Democrats are driving African-American police chiefs out of their jobs.. As the Democratic Party moves to the left this year, it is spending time and energy hoping voters don't notice the consequences of progressive policies. The party famously rolled through its convention across four days without mentioning the violence gripping U.S. cities. Now another hard-to-miss phenomenon has emerged: African-American police chiefs are being forced from their jobs by the party's protesters.

title: Showdown in the Mediterranean
summary: Two NATO allies could go to war over a maritime dispute.. Aegean Sea surface temperatures naturally can reach the 80s, but the region has come to a boil this summer. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's confrontation with Greece over maritime claims could be resolved through diplomacy. The question is whether Mr. Erdogan wants to negotiate or simply assert Turkish power.

title: Trump, Loyalty and 'The Godfather'
summary: His supporters know his flaws but worry that the Democrats will be radical and hurt the economy.. The polls seem to show Joe Biden sailing forward with a solid national lead, and some tightening in the battlegrounds. Nobody knows what's going to happen; after 2016 only dopes are confident. I'm thinking of the larger prevailing currents that may have some impact this year.

title: What Islamists and 'Wokeists' Have in Common
summary: Adherents of both pursue ideological purity, refuse to engage in debate and demand submission.. There were many American heroes on 9/11, but the greatest were the passengers and crew of Flight 93. Not only did they avert what al Qaeda planned-a direct hit on the White House-but they also embodied Patrick Henry's credo "Give me liberty, or give me death!"

title: The Federal Program That Keeps Insulin Prices High
summary: Middlemen pocket discounts while forcing patients, employers and Medicare to pay more.. Perhaps the biggest flashpoint in the political debate about prescription drug prices is the cost of insulin. This summer an executive order from President Trump required low prices for some patients, and Eli Lilly last week announced new measures to make insulin more affordable for diabetics. Yet many aren't aware that a federal program is goosing the price of insulin and other treatments, and keeping the prices high for patients who need these drugs.

title: New Coronavirus Cases Rise in U.S. Despite Slowdown in Testing
summary: U.S. reported more than 34,000 new cases, higher than over the past few days even though testing slowed over Labor Day weekend. Governors in parts of the U.S. took cautious steps toward reopening, as the U.S. reported more than 34,000 new coronavirus cases.

title: Trump's Pennsylvania Bet
summary: He seeks to attract more 'forgotten men' and to limit damage with suburban women.. To watch Donald Trump on the stump is to wonder if this is a campaign with a strategy. To study the Trump re-election effort in Pennsylvania is to understand the carefully calculated bet it is making.

title: 'Having and Being Had' Review: She Can't Win for Losing
summary: By all accounts, the author is doing well. She's a homeowner, bestselling author and creative-writing professor. But it's all come at a cost.. Shortly after moving into a house with her husband and son in 2014, Eula Biss began keeping a special diary. Owning this brick Chicago bungalow gave her "a new sense of security, a feeling of solidity," she writes in her new book, "Having and Being Had," and she felt moved to chronicle her novel feelings of comfort, as well as her discomfort with that comfort. She knew it wouldn't be long before what seemed extraordinary about her life became ordinary, and she felt she should record her uneasy observations about work and class, race and privilege, poverty and pleasure-probe them like a tongue on a canker sore-as a way to hold on to these conflicting feelings and maybe even learn from them.

title: You've Got a Friend This Covid 9/11
summary: How Carole King lifted spirits in New York after the infamous 2001 attacks.. On Friday I'll hold a piece of rubble in my hand, but not just any piece of rubble. It was handed to me by a firefighter at ground zero in October 2001, a few weeks after 9/11. I first visited the site two weeks after the attacks and watched the still smoldering wreckage of what had been the World Trade Center. I was helping coordinate the first memorial service at the site for the families of victims, which was held on Oct. 28.

title: Protests Over Bogotá Police Killing Leave Nine Dead
summary: Authorities call for probe, urge calm after video of officers fatally firing stun gun at restrained cabdriver sparked violent unrest in Colombian capital. BOGOTÁ, Colombia-At least nine people died amid protests that swept this capital overnight, authorities said Thursday, after policemen killed a man while repeatedly firing a stun gun at him as he pleaded for his life in an encounter caught on video.

title: West Coast Wildfires Wreak Havoc Amid Winds and High Temperatures
summary: Fast-moving fires have spread through California, Oregon and Washington, destroying towns and worsening air quality. Wildfires across the American West burned millions of acres and killed a total of at least 15 people by Thursday, as firefighters continued working to contain some of the fastest-growing blazes ever seen.

title: Woodward Book Shows Unguarded Trump on North Korea, Race Issues
summary: 'Rage' includes revelations about administration infighting, North Korea and the president's views on race. WASHINGTON-President Trump bragged that he had saved a Saudi crown prince who the CIA concluded ordered the murder of a U.S. journalist and prominent Saudi critic. He derided U.S. generals as a "bunch of pussies," while his son-in-law and senior adviser dismissed some early White House officials as "overconfident idiots." And some of Mr. Trump's top advisers last year discussed the possible need to speak out about what they viewed as the dangers of his presidency.

title: GOP 'Skinny' Bill on Coronavirus Aid Is Blocked by Democrats in Senate
summary: Bill had 52 votes in favor, 47 opposed, but needed 60 votes to advance. WASHINGTON-Democrats blocked Senate Republicans' whittled-down $300 billion coronavirus aid package from advancing Thursday, as the prospect of passing more relief to households and businesses by Election Day continued to dim.

title: JPMorgan Tells Trading-Floor Staff to Come Back to the Office
summary: The bank, which just notched a record trading quarter, told staffers they need to return by Sept. 21 unless they have child-care or medical issues. One of Wall Street's biggest employers is calling its trading staff back to the office.

title: Photos of the Week
summary: Pope holds first public audience since lockdown, vessel carrying 5,800 cows sinks, Olympique Lyonnais wins fifth consecutive UEFA Women's Champions League title and more. Teachers use a technique called the "zombie check" to encourage social distancing and safe practices at International Leadership of Texas-College Station, a public charter school in College Station, Texas. On the eighth day of opening the school to students, Superintendent Eddie Conger marveled that there were no reported Covid-19 cases, but still was braced for the virus to strike. 'I think everyone is concerned,' he said. 'If they're not concerned, something's wrong with them.' Read more.

title: Oracle Results Bolstered by Cloud-Computing Growth
summary: Company, best known for its in-office database products, has been trying to remake itself. Oracle Corp. is benefiting from increased focus on providing the kind of cloud-computing products and services that have lifted the fortunes of many tech companies.

title: Peloton Posts First-Ever Profit as Pandemic Speeds Sales
summary: At-home fitness bicycle maker expects strong demand to continue into fiscal 2021; revenue projected to double. Peloton Interactive Inc. posted its first-ever quarterly profit as revenue nearly tripled, capitalizing on surging demand for at-home fitness gear during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: U.S. Regulators Fine Pork Giant Smithfield Over Covid-19 Outbreak
summary: Labor Department proposes $13,494 penalty, saying Smithfield failed to provide a safe workplace; Smithfield vows to contest the finding. The U.S. Department of Labor fined Smithfield Foods Inc. over a Covid-19 outbreak that infected nearly 1,300 workers at a South Dakota plant and killed four, alleging that the pork giant failed to protect employees.

title: CFTC Issues Guidance on Corporate Compliance Programs
summary: Memo follows efforts by other agencies to spur investment that prevents regulatory infractions. The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission issued guidance detailing how it will evaluate corporate compliance programs-the latest effort by a U.S. enforcement agency to get companies to invest in programs that prevent regulatory infractions.

title: Women Who Made the American West
summary: From authors to outlaws, female pioneers helped to shape frontier society.. On Sept. 14, 1920, Connecticut became the 37th state to ratify the 19th Amendment, which guaranteed women the right to vote. The exercise was largely symbolic, since ratification had already been achieved thanks to Tennessee on August 18. Still, the fact that Connecticut and the rest of the laggard states were located in the eastern part of the U.S. wasn't a coincidence. Though women are often portrayed in Westerns as either vixens or victims, they played a vital role in the life of the American frontier.

title: Rubio Seeks Security Review of Chinese Bid for GNC
summary: The concern is that Harbin Pharmaceutical of China would gain access to sensitive health data about customers of the struggling vitamin retailer. WASHINGTON-Sen. Marco Rubio on Thursday urged a national-security review panel to scrutinize a Chinese company's attempt to buy struggling vitamin-and-supplement retailer GNC Holdings Inc.

title: New Rules to Make It Easier for New York Parents to Visit Sick Kids
summary: New York Department of Health eases restrictions on visits for the most vulnerable children and teenagers. Children in pediatric nursing homes who haven't been able to hug or kiss their parents for six months will have an easier path to family visits, under new state rules for preventing the spread of coronavirus.

title: With Century 21 Closing, New Yorkers Wonder Which Businesses Are Next
summary: Retailer famous for its discounted luxury labels joins a growing list of New York City fixtures put out of business by coronavirus. New Yorkers mourned the announcement Thursday of Century 21's closure, describing the loss of the department store as a grim sign of what lies ahead for other cherished businesses and institutions with the economy still strained by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: 'Van der Valk' Review: Dutch Treat
summary: An engaging PBS series with an Amsterdam setting and a British cast tracks an acerbic police detective and his colleagues through the canals and alleyways of that capital city.. The creation of a pearl requires an irritant, and beneath the considerable luster of "Van der Valk" lies the gritty Van der Valk himself. As played by Marc Warren ("The Good Wife," "Beecham House"), the Dutch detective is a strutting, sneering, subordinate-abusing sleuth with ice-blue eyes and a chilly soul. Fortunately for "Masterpiece Mystery!" viewers, the three-part PBS series also features a roster of supporting characters too engaging not to render the title character at least tolerable.

title: Jane Fraser to Succeed Michael Corbat as Citi CEO
summary: Fraser would be the first woman to lead a major Wall Street bank. Jane Fraser made a career at Citigroup Inc. doing the hard jobs. She helped set the bank's course after the financial crisis and nursed its battered mortgage business. She mopped up messes in Latin America.

summary: Some eateries plan to hire back staff for indoor dining. New York City restaurant owner Ricky Dolinsky is bringing his staffing levels back to prepandemic levels in light of the state's decision to allow limited indoor dining later this month.

title: 9/11 Responders Give Assist to Coronavirus Essential Workers
summary: Ground Zero workers say the pandemic deserves the same spirit of goodwill that followed the Sept. 11 attacks. title: Police Chief in Bridgeport, Conn., Charged With Fraud
summary: Federal prosecutors say chief and city's personnel director rigged search for head of police. The chief of police in Bridgeport, Conn., was arrested and charged with fraud for allegedly rigging the city's search for a police chief in 2018 to ensure he would be chosen for the post.

title: Private-Equity-Backed iQor Files for Bankruptcy to Cut Debt
summary: Business-services provider seeks chapter 11 protection with a lender-supported plan to erase more than half of its $865 million in long-term debt. Private-equity-backed iQor Holdings Inc., which provides businesses with call centers and collections services, has filed for bankruptcy with a creditor-supported plan to cut about $513 million in debt and hand the business to lenders.

title: Facebook Starts an Ad-Free Section for College Students
summary: But the social-media giant will track its Campus users' activity to ply them with ads elsewhere. Facebook Inc. introduced a new section of its platform to cater just to college students.

title: Google and Twitter Sharpen Tools to Stop False Claims About Election
summary: Social-media companies have faced ongoing pressure to reduce misinformation ahead of U.S. election. Google and Twitter Inc. said they are taking additional steps to tamp down misinformation about the U.S. election, as tech platforms scramble to address an expected flood of false claims and misleading posts ahead of the November vote.

title: 'The Social Dilemma': Sharing a Sense of Dismay
summary: Jeff Orlowski's documentary scrolls through the ways social media warps our perceptions.. Jeff Orlowski's documentary "The Social Dilemma," streaming on Netflix, looks at the myriad ways our minds are twisted and twirled by social media platforms. Most of the strategies were worked out intentionally, though their extreme efficiency may have been unforeseen. One unintended consequence has flowed from the invention of the Like button-yes, it needed to be invented, just like the period or the exclamation point-and speaks with special eloquence to the broader nature of the problem. While the button was under development, recalls Justin Rosenstein, who led the effort at Facebook as an engineering manager, the team's only motivation was to "spread positivity and love in the world." No one could have imagined that teens would become deeply depressed for lack of Likes. Seduced by technology, we are all at the mercy of dimly perceived forces. What the film tells us doesn't constitute breaking news, but its value lies in pulling together some alarming if abstract concepts into a genuinely scary whole.

title: Private Texas Border Wall Will Fall Into Rio Grande, Opponents Say
summary: Engineering reports related to lawsuits cite erosion after Hurricane Hanna; contractor says problem has been remedied. Opponents of a privately funded Texas-Mexico border wall are arguing that land erosion after Hurricane Hanna proves that the wall will fall into the Rio Grande River, citing engineering reports.

title: 9/11 and the Rise of the New Conspiracy Theorists
summary: The persistence of the fringe movement that blames the U.S. government for the 2001 terrorist attacks suggests that QAnon and other digital-age conspiracists may be around for a while. The leaders of the 9/11 Commission wanted to avoid the fate of the Warren Commission. For decades, ambiguities in the report on President John Kennedy's assassination had offered fuel for wild speculation about what had actually happened. "It is extremely difficult to dislodge or anticipate conspiracy theories once they start," said Jamie Gorelick, a member of the 9/11 Commission. The commission's 2004 report was written with such rigor, empirical clarity and narrative power in part to deflate the conspiracy theories already starting to swirl around al Qaeda's attacks on Sept. 11, 2001. "You could see this happening," said Ms. Gorelick.

title: How to Have Safe Sex During the Covid-19 Pandemic
summary: The chance of catching and spreading Covid-19 has added a layer of health concerns, and many questions, when it comes to sexual intimacy. Public health protocols calling for social distancing, wearing face masks and sometimes self-quarantining can be challenging when it comes to intimacy. Health experts and doctors answer some questions about the potential transmission risks associated with certain behavior.

title: 'Pipeline' Review: Facing a Future Behind Bars
summary: In Dominique Morriseau's timely play, streaming on BroadwayHD, a Black couple's teenage son is at risk of imprisonment after he assaults his schoolteacher.. If you're looking for streaming theater webcasts and are prepared to pay the tab, BroadwayHD, a subscription-based digital platform launched five years ago, has more than 200 shows to offer. Many are British productions, but a fair number of the plays and musicals are of American origin (though some are West End transfers of Broadway shows). Several of BroadwayHD's most noteworthy offerings were taped by PBS and telecast as episodes of its "Great Performances" and "Live at Lincoln Center" series, and one of the latter, Lincoln Center Theater's premiere production of Dominique Morriseau's "Pipeline," is a major event.

title: The Unfairness of the CDC's Housing Seizure
summary: A federal eviction moratorium without rental assistance will ultimately harm the very people it aims to help. It will be impossible for housing providers, particularly small owners to continue to provide shelter to their residents.. Your editorial "Trump's Housing Seizure" (Sept. 4) correctly notes that the eviction moratorium imposed by the administration sets a dangerous precedent and places the stability of the entire rental-housing sector in danger. However, encouraging residents struggling to make rent to move to less-expensive homes or banking on an eventual uptick in job creation will not solve the immediate problem at hand.

title: Inflation: Only Real Answer to Government Debt Bloat
summary: The federal government has the option to debase the currency.. Regarding your editorial "Allow Us to Present the Pandemic Bill" (Sept. 3): All debtors, except one, must increase free cash flow to reduce debt. This is achieved by (a) taking in more or (b) spending less. Exception: the federal government, which has (c) the option to debase the currency. For politicians to employ (a) or (b) to reduce federal debt is to invite voter wrath at higher taxes or less government largess. For option (c), liberal politicians can blame wicked corporations for raising prices and champion working families by enacting price controls.

title: LVMH Says Tiffany's Handling of Pandemic Invalidates Merger
summary: French luxury-goods giant had previously cited trade tensions in decision to abandon $16.2 billion acquisition. PARIS- LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton SE blamed Tiffany & Co. for the unraveling of its $16.2 billion takeover, saying the deal was no longer valid because the jeweler had been mismanaged during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Martha Stewart, Sarah Jessica Parker and More on How Life Changed in the Last Decade
summary: We caught up with 13 of our favorite interviewees from the past 10 years to discuss everything from caviar to quarantine looks. Plus, revealing quotes from Tracee Ellis Ross, Gwyneth Paltrow, John Legend and more.. A LOT can change over the course of a decade, like designer Tory Burch's happy place, Jonathan Adler's favorite app and what Instagram ads are resonating with Kate Upton. That's why, in celebration of Off Duty's 10th anniversary, we went back to some of our most entertaining interview subjects-stars in the realms of film, fashion, food, design and travel-to see how their tastes and lives have shifted since we first chatted. Here, you'll learn about Sarah Jessica Parker's lockdown uniform, Martha Stewart's (and her grandson's) caviar preferences, David Lynch's devotion to espresso, and more non-essential but amusing celebrity tidbits. We've also revisited 10 notable quotes from stars including Tracee Ellis Ross, Gwyneth Paltrow, John Legend and Cate Blanchett. Join the glitterati for a brisk walk down memory lane.

title: Williams as Othello and Wokeness Hurting Diversity
summary: Bravo that a woman is cast and performs admirably as a man in a classic work of theater! Contrast that with the expressed outrage over Adele "appropriating" some African hairstyle.. Williams (she/her) as Othello in his review of the American Shakespeare Center production directed by Ethan McSweeny ("'Othello': A Work of Fitting Gravitas," Arts in Review, Sept. 4). Bravo that a woman is cast and performs admirably as a man in a classic work of theater! Contrast that with the expressed outrage over Adele Adkins "appropriating" some African hairstyle.

But even in this year like no other, fall remains the season of new releases. In this year's Fall Preview, the Journal looks at what is coming in movies, TV, books, podcasts and mediums in between.

title: Lagarde's Optimism on Europe's Economy Triggers Euro Rally
summary: ECB chief says the eurozone economy is experiencing a strong rebound; euro jumps against the dollar. summary: Backups stretch into inland distribution channels as importers rush to restock and prepare for the holiday sales season. summary: Governments want to help parents get to work and avoid lost classroom time for students; 'we have a moral duty'. summary: Jane Fraser to start with solid foundation, but the pandemic keeps credit cards a major pivot point for globe-spanning bank. Next year, Citigroup will have a new chief executive for the first time in nearly a decade. But it will still face some familiar challenges.

title: God, Parents and the '1619 Project'
summary: Religious Americans should reject the idea that slavery is what defines the nation.. President Trump tweeted on Sunday that the Education Department is "looking at" whether public schools were teaching the New York Times ' "1619 Project," which argues that the U.S. is a corrupt country fundamentally built on slavery. Historians have shown in these pages why this is false and a harmful idea, but there are also reasons for religious Americans to reject this revision of history.

title: Megyn Kelly Is Back, but This Time She's Podcasting

title: U.S. Says It Is Cracking Down on PPP Fraud

WASHINGTON-Federal authorities sought Thursday to underscore their efforts to combat fraud in the government's coronavirus relief program for small business, pointing to charges filed against 57 people for alleged crimes related to the Paycheck Protection Program.

title: A Viral Video Asks a Deep Question
summary: How do we know that math is real, and who came up with it in the first place?. A young woman called Gracie went unexpectedly viral last month when she posted a video on TikTok questioning whether math is real. While putting on makeup, she wonders how anyone came up with algebra in the first place and how we know it's right. Online reactions have been typically polarized: Some commenters derided her for being dumb, while others-including mathematicians and physicists-found her questions deep. They get to the heart of what math is and what it is for.

title: Second Night of Fires Destroys Remains of Greek Refugee Camp
summary: Authorities scramble to rehouse some 12,000 people living in compound on island of Lesbos. ATHENS-A second night of fires destroyed what was left of Europe's biggest refugee camp, on the Greek island of Lesbos, as Greek authorities scrambled to rehouse some 12,000 people who were living in the camp.

title: A Secretive Berlin Club Closed for Covid-19 Reopens as Art Gallery
summary: Berghain has opened its doors to the public with an exhibition featuring paintings, video, sound, sculptures, photography and performance art. BERLIN-Six months into Berlin's pandemic-induced clubbing ban, the city's most famous dance venue is trying something different: brightly illuminated contemporary art, silence and a friendly door policy.

title: Century 21 Files for Bankruptcy, to Close All 13 Stores
summary: New York flagship store, which offered deep discounts on designer clothing and accessories, plus 12 others will begin going-out-of-business sales. Century 21, where generations of New Yorkers shopped for deep discounts on everything from Prada handbags to Jerry Garcia ties, filed for bankruptcy, the latest retailer to fall victim to disruptions caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: A Step Toward Accountability in Policing
summary: Reformers are taking aim at the doctrine of 'qualified immunity,' which protects government officials from liability for violating the rights of citizens.. As the nation roils over police abuse and racial injustice, Democrats and Republicans often disagree about how best to respond. But on one matter there is significant agreement: The judge-made doctrine of "qualified immunity" is part of the problem. That rule provides that victims whose constitutional rights were violated can't sue police officers or other government officials for damages, unless the actions were so egregious that no reasonable officer would believe them lawful. In practice, it means that countless violations go entirely unremedied.

title: New York Fed Seeks to Diversify Firms Providing Emergency Support
summary: Daleep Singh, who leads the New York Fed's markets group, says the central bank's support efforts have been effective. A top New York Fed official said the Federal Reserve is trying to broaden who can take part in its pandemic emergency support efforts.

title: Kroger Spent Hundreds of Millions on Tech Before Covid-19, but It Wasn't Enough
summary: Plans for big warehouses and driverless delivery weren't ready when the pandemic supercharged online demand. Kroger Co. has spent years-and hundreds of millions of dollars-investing in technology to give it a digital edge in the grocery business. But when the coronavirus changed customers' buying habits overnight, the grocery chain wasn't as ready for the online shift as some of its competitors.

title: Some New York Schools Switch to Remote Learning After Funding Cuts
summary: Albany's layoffs were some of the first direct fallout from Gov. Cuomo's administration withholding aid as the state grapples with a $14.5 billion deficit. ALBANY, N.Y.-Middle- and high-school students in the state's capital city would have had the option of some classroom time this fall semester under the district's reopening plan.

title: Top 10 Design Trends of the Next Decade: Meet Your New Home
summary: We asked hundreds of interior designers and architects to predict the next big residential trends. Here are their picks-from multi-generational living to less-gargantuan sofas. Plus: A look back at our best and worst design predictions from the 2010s.. WHEN WE asked interior designers and architects to look into the future, we knew the impact of coronavirus would be a factor. But some of the trends the pros named were already influencing design before Covid-19-the virus merely pushed them to a tipping point. Take Chicago designer Wendy Labrum's prognostication that enthusiasm for open plans will wither: "We've thankfully seen a trend away from the cookie-cutter open-concept floor plan in recent years, and I would suspect the pandemic will only put a nail in that proverbial coffin." So too with the multigenerational home. This antidote to expensive solo living became more urgent after the quarantine separated grandparents from grandkids, and independent children moved home. Here, the ten trends design pros see coming to your door, none of them woeful.

title: Fiat Chrysler Looks to Maserati to Jump-Start Stalled European Business
summary: Italian-American firm unveils luxury sports car, storied brand's first new vehicle for four years. MODENA, Italy-Fiat Chrysler Automobile NV's years of struggles in Europe faded for an evening as its Maserati brand lavishly unveiled a new luxury sports car it hopes will reinvigorate the unprofitable marque.

title: Unemployment Claims Held Steady Last Week
summary: Jobless claims are nearly four times levels seen before the coronavirus upended the economy in March. The number of people seeking and collecting unemployment benefits has remained at historically high levels in recent weeks, a sign the labor-market recovery is losing steam six months after the pandemic struck the U.S.

title: Restaurant Critics Acquire New Tastes: Takeout, Frozen Food, Home Cooking
summary: With restaurants still closed or operating at limited capacity, food critics are evaluating new fare, including their own preparations; 'I'm very critical of myself'. title: The Yankees Were World Series Favorites. Now They Might Not Make the Playoffs.
summary: Despite a powerful lineup, a rotation led by Gerrit Cole and an expanded postseason, New York could finish below .500 for the first time since 1992. When the New York Yankees trudged off the field at Houston's Minute Maid Mark last October, still reeling from the shock of José Altuve's pennant-clinching home run, they faced a disquieting reality. For the first time in more than a century, the most successful franchise in American sports history had gone an entire calendar decade without a single trip to the World Series.

title: Elon Musk's Payday Could Cost Tesla Shareholders Dearly
summary: The accounting effect of options awards for Tesla's CEO could push it into a loss and disqualify the company from S&P 500 index inclusion for a long time. Thanks to Tesla 's meteoric share-price rise, Elon Musk is set to cash in on a huge bonus package. Shareholders counting on their own tidy fortunes should know how Mr. Musk's payday might dent their prospects. The inclusion of Tesla in the benchmark S&P 500 index could face a further major delay because of the accounting impact.

summary: Ban on use of technology in public spaces is a first, experts say. Portland City Council passed a sweeping limit on commercial use of facial-recognition technology that experts say is the strongest such rule in the U.S.

title: Airbnb Owns Today's Travelers, But What About Tomorrow's?
summary: Home-sharing giant's success as public company depends on how the appetite for homestays fits into the future of travel. With the future of travel up in the air, Airbnb appears to be capitalizing on travelers staying grounded-for now.

title: Oil Major BP Gives a Taste of How It Will Go Green
summary: Deal to buy into wind farms off New York and Massachusetts showcases U.K. firm's ambitions in clean energy. Last month oil and gas giant BP laid out the theory of how it aims to become a clean-energy company. Now it has served up a taste of what that might mean in practice.

title: A Peek Inside the Elite Homes of the Art World
summary: A new book tours the art-filled homes of gallerists and dealers.. Like a hand-colored atlas or a lavish birding guide, For Art's Sake: Inside the Homes of Art Dealers ($85; rizzoliusa.com) hints at the riches of a larger experience-in this case, the international art circuit-without nudging the reader off the couch. Venezuelan-born collector Tiqui Atencio Demirdjian convinced prominent gallerists, including Paula Cooper, Marian Goodman and Barbara Gladstone, to open their homes for the book. "I wanted to see how major art dealers became who they are," Atencio Demirdjian says, "and what art they privilege." As chair of the Guggenheim museum's International Director's Council and the Latin American acquisition committee at the Tate, Atencio Demirdjian is a regular at exhibition openings and global fairs, and she's known most of her subjects for years.

title: Making Cotton Into Concrete for Alexander McQueen
summary: Architect Smiljan Radić is redefining the boutique look of Alexander McQueen's stores in time for the retail revolution. Chilean architect Smiljan Radić looks sharp in a manta, the V-neck pullover that's traditional attire in the mountains south of Santiago, where he has a small country house. "It's more than clothing. It's a piece of my history," he says of his favorite one, a heap of silky brown vicuña that formerly belonged to his great-grandfather. "In the city I never use it. It would be ridiculous."

Come on! This is the NFL, people-the mightiest, most self-assured sports league in the land. This is a league that decided people had nothing better to do than to watch professional football played on a Thursday night-and they were right. We really have nothing better to do.

title: Europe's Telcos Are Due Their Time in the Sun

If investors start to see them that way, one of Europe's worst-performing sectors could finally turn a corner.

title: How Biden's Tax Plan Would Affect Five American Households
summary: Tax increases are aimed at those making more than $400,000, and households at the very top of the income scale would see the biggest rises. title: In Covid Times, Consumers Want Float for Their Boat

title: Fed Needs Fiscal Support to Close Gap Between Markets, Real Economy
summary: Federal Reserve's ability to support the economy absent fiscal support is limited, but its effect on markets remains profound. title: Election 2020 Polls: Startups Pitch Themselves as Alternatives
summary: Many campaigns, political groups still pay for polling, but use online surveys and social-media analysis to understand voters. Four years after President Trump surprised many Americans by outperforming polls in battleground states, a cottage industry of political tech startups has sprung up to predict voter preferences ahead of the 2020 election.

title: AstraZeneca CEO Sees Oxford Vaccine Possible by End of Year, Despite Setback
summary: Late-stage trial was paused after a participant in the U.K. developed an unexplained illness. LONDON- AstraZeneca PLC's chief executive said a Covid-19 vaccine it is developing with the University of Oxford could still be ready by the end of the year, despite the company pausing late-stage trials after a participant in the U.K. developed an unexplained illness.

title: Kenosha Businesses Grapple With Damage to City
summary: Uptown's minority-owned businesses ask why looters came for them after Jacob Blake shooting: 'They were destroying the neighborhoods that they want to protect'. KENOSHA, Wis.-La Estrella Supermarket, the neighborhood grocery. Uptown Beauty, the mom-and-pop supply shop. Uptown Restaurant, the locally-owned eatery. They have stood side-by-side on 22nd Avenue for years, serving Kenosha's diverse Uptown neighborhood even as other storefronts closed or were lured toward high-traffic areas near the interstate.

title: Oil Traders Gird for More Price Swings
summary: Recent volatility ended a stretch of calm in the oil market. Many are using options markets to bet more drama is to come.. Traders are betting on fresh upheaval in the oil market, in an abrupt turnaround from the calm of recent months.

title: Fed Debates How to Implement New Policy Strategy
summary: Officials will deliberate how to provide more specific guidance about a low interest rate path at the Sept. 15-16 meeting. In preparing for a September meeting, they are debating how exactly to implement this strategy for an economy recovering from a severe and unusual downturn.

title: Pandemic Tech Spending in China Lifts Alibaba's Cloud
summary: Businesses in China are accelerating their digitization efforts, helping make local cloud providers into giants to rival Amazon and Microsoft. Spending on China-based cloud services hit a record high in the second quarter as Chinese companies increased the use of online business tools in the aftermath of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Several Covid-19 Vaccines Could Join Winner's Circle
summary: Several coronavirus vaccines could pass muster in clinical trials, with distribution in phases starting as soon as this fall, experts say. The first vaccine that proves to safely protect people against Covid-19 disease will be a breakthrough moment but is unlikely to be the sole answer to curbing the coronavirus pandemic.

title: U.S. Government Sells a Hong Kong Compound for $332 Million
summary: The site includes 26 apartments in six buildings, and a swimming pool. The U.S. government agreed to sell a compound for consulate staff in one of Hong Kong's most exclusive residential areas to a local developer for nearly a third of a billion dollars.

title: New York Islanders Fans Finally Have Something to Cheer About

title: Covid-19 Death Toll in U.S. Tops 190,000
summary: New coronavirus cases rise at a slower pace than in recent months, coinciding with a drop in testing. The nation's death toll attributed to Covid-19 surpassed 190,000 on Wednesday, according to data from Johns Hopkins University, while new coronavirus cases in the U.S. rose by more than 26,000 on Tuesday, well below the daily tallies of recent months. However, the lower daily count also coincided with a recent decline in testing.

title: Wildfires Grow on West Coast and Darken San Francisco Region
summary: As blazes cause evacuation orders in California, Oregon and Washington, Bay Area residents look in vain for the sun. High winds fueled explosive growth in wildfires raging across the West Coast late Tuesday and Wednesday and coated the San Francisco Bay Area in smoke so thick that it was dark at noon.

title: Western Businesses in China Fret as Geopolitical Risks Rise
summary: Surveys of U.S. and European companies show greater concern over political headwinds.

title: Trump, in Bob Woodward Interview, Said He Played Down Coronavirus's Severity
summary: 'I don't want to create a panic,' president said in recordings for new book; public-health experts say the move harmed efforts to prevent virus's spread. WASHINGTON-President Trump told journalist Bob Woodward in March that he was deliberately playing down the severity of the coronavirus to avoid inciting panic as he publicly dismissed the virus's threat in a way public-health experts say harmed the ability to restrict its spread.

title: Biden Pushes Higher Taxes on U.S. Companies' Foreign Profits in Pitch to Midwest Voters
summary: Democratic presidential candidate would raise taxes as part of his 'Made in America' plan. Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden called Wednesday for higher taxes on U.S. companies' foreign income and special tax breaks for domestic manufacturing, appealing to blue-collar workers during a trip to Michigan.

title: Former New York Gynecologist Faces Federal Charges of Abusing Patients
summary: U.S. prosecutors allege that Robert Hadden enticed victims to travel and engage in illegal sex acts. A former Manhattan gynecologist was arrested Wednesday and charged with sexually abusing patients.

title: Trump's Latest Judicial List
summary: Some solid judges but three Senators make the choices disappointingly political.. Donald Trump's 2016 list of potential Supreme Court nominees helped solidify conservative support for his campaign, and as President he's followed through. Mr. Trump's mark on the federal judiciary-including two Supreme Court Justices and 53 appellate judges-is one of his notable successes. On Wednesday his campaign released 20 more potential Supreme Court nominees. And while there are strong picks, the list also shows that the campaign has traded some legal seriousness for political signaling.
